config.question: Why did Grover Cleveland veto more bills than all of his predecessors combined?

choices.content: He wanted to reduce the role of the federal government.
He wanted to become more prominent on the national stage.
He opposed legislation introduced by the Democrats.
He opposed lackluster legislation, in favor of more radical reform.

answer_3.response: In the election of 1884, Grover Cleveland, the Democratic governor of New York, won a narrow victory. The first Democratic president since 1861, Cleveland reflected his party’s desire to curtail federal activities. He vetoed more than two-thirds of the bills presented to him, more than all his predecessors combined.
